table.name: mem
table.column: This word or a homophone appears to be a component of {lolSeHcha:n} and {'eDSeHcha:n}, which suggests that perhaps {cha:n:nolink} can mean "rockets" in some contexts, or used to in the past.

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang term derives from the similarity in the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect of {chab:n:1} to {cham:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "new pie". This slang term derives from the similarity in the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect of {chab:n:1} to {cham:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Wunsch, etwas das man sich wünscht

table.name: mem
table.column: This was originally defined as "emergency" in {TKD:src}, and its meaning was then expanded to include "auxiliary, backup" in a vocabulary list first published in {veS QonoS:src} then reprinted in {HQ 1.3, Sept. 1992:src}. Note that a noun-noun construction containing {chach:n:nolink} might have a different meaning depending on whether {chach:n:nolink} is the first or second noun in the compound.
▶ {tlham chach chu'qa'@@tlham:n:1, chach:n, chu':v:2, -qa':v} "Restoring auxiliary gravity"[3] ▶ {chach Duj:n}[4]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: close female friend of a female

table.name: mem
table.column: In the novel {Sarek:src}, {chal:n:nolink} is also the name of a type of flower.

table.name: mem
table.column: This term doesn't appear in canon, but rather was invented for a blog post about science. It's here so that someone else doesn't invent a different term.
This term was coined by Felix Malmenbeck ({loghaD:n:nolink}), and roughly means "sky-crystal gunpowder".

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Romulan Star Empire.
The fact that the name of this planet appears to be "inhabited sky" in Klingon (see {chal:n}, {toq:v}) seems to be a coincidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is in the direction of the sunrise.[1] It is 90 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.
China is in the east (from the perspective of Europe or America).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is kept in a large {bal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a regional word for {qettlhup:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Chang and Eng Bunker were a famous pair of Siamese twins.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's quite common for the backs of one's hands to become "chap"ped.

table.name: mem
table.column: thrust upward with end of bat'leth

table.name: mem
table.column: There have been a number of conquerors named Charles.

table.name: mem
table.column: top of walking cane or ceremonial cane

table.name: mem
table.column: This contains less liquid than found in what a Terran might identify as soup. It is served in a {maHpIn:n}, and eaten in a {Duq:n}.
The fact that this is eaten in a {Duq:n:nolink} may be a reference to the Marx Brothers film "Duck Soup".

table.name: mem
table.column: The slang meaning may be a reference to the Marx Brothers film "Duck Soup".

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: ▶ {QaghwIj vIQIj 'e' yIchaw'neS.} "Permit me to explain my mistake, your honor."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used for a broader range of objects than the translation "permit" suggests. Kinds of {chaw':n:nolink} include {HIjmeH chaw':n}, {Huch chaw':n}, {leng chaw':n}, {lojmIt chaw':n:nolink}, {yer ghajwI' chaw':n}, and {'elmeH chaw':n}. Thus, {chaw':n:nolink} can also mean "ticket", "pass", or "license".
A {chaw':n:nolink} shows that you are officially or legally allowed to do or get or own something, whereas a {Qoyje':n} serves as proof or verification of some sort of achievement or accomplishment.[3]
This is missing from the K-E side of {TKD:src}.
▶ {cha'puj vIngevmeH chaw' HInobneS.} "Give me a permit to sell dilithium, your honor."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chay' jura'?} "What are your orders?", or literally, "How do you (sing.) command us?"

table.name: mem
table.column: How did this happen? What's going on?

table.name: mem
table.column: How do I use this? What do I do with this?

table.name: mem
table.column: The first ever line of Klingon spoken on-screen was {wIy cha'@@wIy:n, cha':v}, in {Star Trek I:src}.

▶ {tlhIngan Dujmey law'qu' SommeyDaq batlh cha'lu'.@@tlhIngan:n, Duj:n:2, -mey:n, law':v, -qu':v, Som:n, -mey:n, -Daq:n, batlh:adv, cha':v, -lu':v} "[It] has been emblazoned upon the hulls of countless Klingon Starships."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird noted for its speed

table.name: mem
table.column: During some legal proceedings, the accused must have a second to defend him or her.

table.name: mem
table.column: a species of Klingon bird about which little is known
Klingonischer Vogel über den wenig bekannt ist

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons have twenty-three ribs ({joQ:n:1,body}). This expression means that something is not quite right.
▶ {naDev cha'maH cha' joQDu' tu'lu':sen:nolink} (this means something strange is going on) ▶ {cha'maH cha' joQDu' ghaj qama':sen:nolink} "The prisoner has twenty-two ribs", i.e., he's a bit strange

table.name: mem
table.column: a small bird which digs up bugs to eat
kleiner Vogel welcher Käfer zur Nahrung ausgräbt

table.name: mem
table.column: Pun: "forearms" sounds like "four arms", but there are only two ({cha':n:num}, {neH:adv}).

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird noted for its song

This is a reference to Charlie Parker, an American Jazz musician known by the nickname "Yardbird", or "Bird" for short.
Also, in Spanish, "parpar" is the sound made by a duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha'puj tlhIlHal vISuch vIneH.} "I want to visit the dilithium mines."[2] ▶ {cha'puj vIngevmeH chaw' HInobneS.} "Give me a permit to sell dilithium, your honor."[3] ▶ {yuQ SumDaq cha'puj law' Datu'.} "Detect large sums of dilithium on nearby planet."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: Crude dilithium crystal is called {Dom:n}.[1] Chrystalline dilithium is used as the reaction moderating element ({choH lISbogh Hap'e':n}) in a Klingon Bird of Prey.[2] The verb {chIm:v} is used for a drained dilithium crystal.[3]
▶ {cha'pujqutmey vIje' vIneHbej!} "I definitely want to buy dilithium crystals!"[4] ▶ {cha'pujqutmey chIm lutamlu'.} "Drained dilithium crystals are replaced."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird with a noisy, repetitive cry
A "cuckoo", as in a cuckoo clock.

table.name: mem
table.column: This ale is too potent for tourists.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that this word is singular, unlike the English word "scissors".

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "we hit targets". Note that {DoSmey:n:nolink} must be used, not the inherent plural {ray':n}. This idiom can be shortened to just {DoSmey DIqIp.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression means that two people are involved in a single activity and no one else is. For example, a duel may be described by saying {Suv cha' qabDu':sen:nolink} "Two faces are fighting", "Two people are fighting one-on-one".
one on one, one-on-one, face to face, face-to-face

table.name: mem
table.column: unit of weight, mass (approx. 5 lbs or 2.25 kg)
Since gravity on Kronos is different than that on Earth, it's not really clear what the exact value of this unit is, or whether it measures weight or mass.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the {BoP:src} poster, 8.7KT = 375 000 {cheb'a':n:nolink}. It is likely that one {cheb'a':n:nolink} is equal to nine {cheb:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: An alcoholic beverage best served heated and steaming.[1] Its name appears to be composed of {chech:v} and {tlhutlh:v}.[2]
In the K-E side, this is given as "baceh'tluth". This is commonly assumed to be a typo, or perhaps a joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the place to which the subject returns (if it is not mentioned, the verb takes a prefix indicating no object). If the return is forced, use {tatlh'egh:v} instead.[5]

▶ {ghorgh pa'wIjDaq jIchegh?@@ghorgh:ques, pa':n:1, -wIj:n, -Daq:n, jI-:v, chegh:v} "When can I return to my room?"[2] ▶ {wa'leS jIchegh.} "Tomorrow I will return."[3] ▶ {DaH machegh.}[4]
The following four examples illustrate the role of the object(s) and how to use {chegh:v:nolink} with {-Daq:n} and {-vo':n}[5]: ▶ {lupDujHomDaq jIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return on the shuttle." ▶ {lupDujHom vIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the shuttle." ▶ {lupDujHomDaq may'Duj vIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the battle cruiser on the shuttle" ▶ {tera'vo' Qo'noS vIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return to Kronos from Earth"

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons have two livers.[1, p.28] (See also {bIraqlul:n}.)

table.name: mem
table.column: For the mathematical operation of addition, see {boq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The element {chem:n:hyp,nolink} is not known to appear by itself, but is found in the words {HoSchem:n}, {peQchem:n}, {pIvchem:n}, and {Surchem:n}.
In {TKDA:src}, {peQ chem:n:nolink} actually appears as two words (with a space).

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingon women make sounds like a {chemvaH:n:nolink} to indicate interest in a potential mate.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used to indicate the result of mathematical operations.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the verb {chen:v} with the suffix {-moH:v}, so verb suffixes of types 1 to 3 need to go before {-moH:v}, which is type 4.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: General Chang ({cheng Sa':n:nolink}) was a character in {Star Trek VI:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?
Tickle us, do we not laugh? Prick us, do we not bleed? Wrong us, shall we not seek revenge?
This is a paraphrase of a famous passage from Shakespeare's {The Merchant of Venice:src}, Act III, scene i.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word sounds like "chair", but {che':v} is closer in meaning to "chair".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an animal with long ears, similar to an Earth rabbit.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the dialect of {voSpegh Sep:n}, this refers to any coat or jacket (what other Klingons would call a {wep:n:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {lo'laHbe'; chetvI' chIm rur}.
The distinction between a {chetvI':n:nolink} and a {DuS:n} has to do with how the projectile is loaded.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a stick with a hook at the end, which is used as an aid in throwing (see {wob:v}) a {tlhevjaQ:n}.
This item, as described in {KGT:src}, would seem to be an "atlatl".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This almost sounds like "chair".
This word is defined in {TKD:src} as "rule, reign, run" and additionally in {KGT:src} as "preside".

▶ {juHqo'Daq vaS'a' tu'lu'. ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'. DaH che' ghawran. yejquv DevwI' moj ghawran 'e' wuqta' cho' 'oDwI' Dapu'bogh janluq pIqarD HoD.:sen:nolink} "On the Homeworld, there is a great hall where the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire. Gowron currently presides, named leader of the High Council by Captain Jean-Luc Picard, who was acting as Arbiter of Succession."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Cheron" was the name of the planet in {TOS - Let That Be Your Last Battlefield:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The expression {Dujmey law' chIjpu':sen:idiom} means that somebody is experienced.

table.name: mem
table.column: The idiomatic expression {DoS chIl:sen:idiom} means "to digress", e.g., {DoS vIchIl:sen:nolink} means "I digress".

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {chIm:v} is used for a drained dilithium crystal.
▶ {cha'pujqutmey chIm lutamlu'.} "Drained dilithium crystals are replaced."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Why did the "chick"en cross the road?

table.name: mem
table.column: total dishonor, absolute lack of honor
The first part of the example sentence was a lip-match for {mughojmoH parmaqqaywI'}. The second part was a lip-match for a sentence beginning with {naDevvo'}.

▶ {potlhmo' batlh, vIqawba', 'ej chIvo' neH chIw vum'e'.@@potlh:v, -mo':v, batlh:n, vI-:v, qaw:v, -ba':v, 'ej:conj, chIvo':n, neH:adv, chIw:v, vum:n, -'e':n} "Because you care about honor. And this man has none."
total dishonour, absolute lack of honour

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {potlhmo' batlh, vIqawba', 'ej chIvo' neH chIw vum'e'.@@potlh:v, -mo':v, batlh:n, vI-:v, qaw:v, -ba':v, 'ej:conj, chIvo':n, neH:adv, chIw:v, vum:n, -'e':n} "Because you care about honor. And this man has none."

table.name: mem
table.column: stairway leading to a door of a ship, gangplank
Stufen zum Eingang eines Raumschiffs; Laufsteg, Steg

table.name: mem
table.column: This was used to translate "update" (change the value of a variable) in Klingon Blockly.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also refer to a chemical or nuclear reaction.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears on the {BoP:src} poster in the specification: {choH lISbogh Hap'e' - cha'pujqut:sen:nolink} "Reaction Moderating Element - Crystalline Dilithium".

table.name: mem
table.column: close in, get closer, come nearer

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unknown why this word appears to combine {chol:v} and {jaH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In a Klingon bar, the bartender shouts {'eb Qav:n} for "last call".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be profound, be thorough, be careful; be good, be excellent
This word is applied to a person's intellect, and expresses a meaning equivalent to {Qubchu'}. It is also used by itself as an expression of approval, similar to {maj:excl}.[1, p.148]

table.name: mem
table.column: Watch a performance of {HIchop!:sen:lyr} by Jen Usellis: {YouTube video:url:http://www.youtube.com/v/v2bjc6U0tjI}

This is almost a "chomp".
In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", the British expression "Give us a kiss, love." was translated as {HIchop, bang.:sen:nolink}[3]
▶ {lIchopbe'chugh ghewmey.:sen:nolink} "If the bugs do not bite you."[2] ▶ {'uSDaj chop, chev!:sen:nolink} "Bite his/her leg off!"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2] ▶ {wo' ngay' bochoqmeH bowIvlu'pu'!:sen:nolink} "You have been chosen to preserve the glory of the Empire!"[3].

table.name: mem
table.column:
This phrase is used when speaking to one person. When speaking to a group of people, say {tuquvmoH.:sen}
If the person you're speaking to is your superior, consider adding {-neS:v:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha' vI' vagh choQmey lutoghlu':sen:nolink} "Number of Decks: 2.5"[1] ▶ {cha' choQmey naQ tu'lu' 'ej tep choQ bIngDaq lo' law' bID choQ tu'lu':sen:nolink} "2 Full Decks and a Half Utility Deck under the Cargo Deck"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the exterior midsection of the body. To refer to a stomach (an internal organ), use {burgh:n} instead.
This is defined in {TKD:src} as "belly".[1] The gloss "midsection" comes from {FTG:src}.[2]
▶ {tajwIj 'oHbe' chorlIj jeqbogh Dochvetlh'e'.:sen:nolink} "That is not my dagger protruding from your midsection."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {bargh:n} made of ceramic. This word can also be shortened to {chor:n:2,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: eighth tone of nonatonic music scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2,nolink}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that there are two twilights in a day ({jaj:n}), one in the morning and one in the evening.

This is defined in {TKD:src} as "twilight" only. However, in {TNK:src}, the Terran expression "Good evening" is translated into Klingon as {maj choS:excl:nolink} (see {maj:excl}), suggesting that this word can also mean "evening" to a Klingon, at least in context.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. However, it follows the pattern of the other {tay:n:1} words, and is included here for reference.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {juHqo'Daq vaS'a' tu'lu'. ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'. DaH che' ghawran. yejquv DevwI' moj ghawran 'e' wuqta' cho' 'oDwI' Dapu'bogh janluq pIqarD HoD.:sen:nolink} "On the Homeworld, there is a great hall where the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire. Gowron currently presides, named leader of the High Council by Captain Jean-Luc Picard, who was acting as Arbiter of Succession."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: people, kin, member of the same group or tribe or clan
Leute, Mitglieder einer Gruppe, eines Stamms, eines Clans
This may have been a back-fit for a mispronunciation of {jup:n}.
▶ {Qob lIb bam SoH chuDlI' je.@@Qob:n, lIb:v, bam:v, SoH:n, chuD:n, -lI':n, je:conj} "You and your people are in danger."

table.name: mem
table.column: throw (a spear) at, hurl (a spear) at

This verb can only be used if the projectile is or resembles a spear. The object of this verb is the intended target. The suffix {-chu':v:suff} is used with this verb to indicate that the target is actually hit. [1, p.64]

table.name: mem
table.column: explain clearly to, clarify for, specify for

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was awarded to {Qov:n:name,nolink} as a Friend of Maltz, hence the Canadian spelling in the definition.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {ghu':n} can be used to refer to a proposal (a proposed situation); that is, one can {chup:v} a {ghu':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a class of people.

That this word refers to a class of people, rather than to an abstract concept, is supported by the script of "Elaan of Troyius", the only TOS episode with both Klingons and dialogue referring to nobility. The words {Doy'yuS:n}, {'elaS:n}, {telun Hovtay':n}, and {Dom:n} likewise appear only in this episode.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary of {A Burning House:src}, this is a rodent that mostly lives underground and makes an annoying noise. Its name literally means "one which is noisy".

table.name: mem
table.column: This seems to be composed of {chuS:v} and {'ugh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for leftover food. However, the core of an apple, which isn't eaten, is {SuqSIv:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {chuvmey:n:nolink} include pronouns, numbers, conjunctions, adverbials, and exclamations.

table.name: mem
table.column:
"Achoo!"
The noun {chuyDaH:n} seems to imply that this verb, or a homophone, can be used to describe the expulsion of gas at a high velocity.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Types of thrusters include {'eDSeHcha:n}, {lolSeHcha:n}, {muDDaq 'eDSeHcha lulaQlu'bogh:n}, {Hong boq chuyDaH:n}, and {'o' chuyDaH:n}.
Watch Gowron say {chuyDaH yIlaQ!:sen:nolink}: {YouTube video:url:http://www.youtube.com/v/KKZoYsbxUjY}
{DaH:n} appears to be "array", and {chuy:v:nolink} may be related to the verb "to sneeze".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not defined as such in canon, but appears in the bodies of {TKD:src} and {KGT:src}[1; 2]. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: The glossary to {A Burning House:src} claims that {chu'wI':n:nolink} meaning "trigger" is also slang for "rookie", "beginner", or "newbie". See {chu':v:1}.
